definition: level or even tone/first and second tones in modern Mandarin
surname Ping
flat/level/equal/to tie (make the same score)/to draw (score)/calm/peaceful/see also 平聲|平声[ping2 sheng1]
sound/voice/tone/noise/reputation/classifier for sounds
to restrict to even tone (i.e. final rhyming syllable must be classical first or second tone 平聲|平声)
high and level tone, the first tone of putonghua
evenly rising tone, the second tone of putonghua

sentences.english: The level tone feet of the metrical verse embodies the harmony of parole of language.
sentences.chinese: 平声韵脚充分体现出了言语与语言之间的和谐互动。

sentences.english: Listen, I don't want to have it out with you. Can we just talk about it quietly?
sentences.chinese: 听着，我不想跟你争吵。我们能平声静气地谈吗？

sentences.english: "Analects of Confucius" in the "theory" should read as Ping Sheng, as early as the conclusion.
sentences.chinese: 《论语》中的“论”须读为平声，早为定论。

definition: oblique tone/nonlevel tone/uneven tone (the third tone of Classical Chinese)
falling tone/fourth tone in modern Mandarin
entering tone/checked tone/one of the four tones of Middle Chinese
to tilt/narrow/uneasy/oblique tones (in Chinese poetry)
falling and rising tone/third tone in modern Mandarin
level and oblique tones (technical term for Classical Chinese rhythmic poetry)
the final of a Chinese syllable (the component of a syllable remaining after removal of the initial consonant, if any, and the tone, e.g. the final of "niáng" is "iang")
(phonology) coda, the part of a syllable that follows its vocalic nucleus (e.g. "u" in kòu or "n" in běn)
evenly rising tone, the second tone of putonghua
fourth tone in Mandarin/falling tone
the four tones of Middle Chinese: level tone 平聲|平声, rising tone 上聲|上声, departing tone 去聲|去声 and entering tone 入聲|入声/the four tones of Modern Standard Mandarin
phonetic value of a character
to rhyme
consonant/the initial consonant (of a Chinese syllable)
(Chinese linguistics) zero initial (the initial of a syllable that does not begin with a consonant)
main vowel in diphthong
